ESPN managed to establish itself as the go-to sports network by making several strategic moves, some of which I mentioned earlier. Here are a few more ways they did it:

1. Emphasis on Storytelling: ESPN excelled in storytelling through its various programming like 30 for 30, E:60, and SC Featured. These shows were able to capture the human interest element in sports and attract a wider audience.

2. Live Event Rights: ESPN acquired live rights to many major sporting events, including the NFL, NBA, MLB, NCAA, and international events like the Olympics. Having exclusive live rights to these events attracted a large audience base and made ESPN the go-to network for sports fans.

3. Collaborations and Partnerships: ESPN partnered with other major sports networks, including ABC and NBC to expand its reach. They also collaborated with leagues like the NBA and NFL to create unique programming and exclusive content.

4. Talent Acquisition: ESPN was successful in acquiring and developing talent, including broadcasters and analysts like Chris Berman, Stuart Scott, and Dan Patrick. This gave the network a distinct personality and helped it stand out from its competitors.

5. Innovation: ESPN was always on the cutting edge of technology and innovation. From its pioneering use of the scrolling ticker to its mobile app, ESPN was always at the forefront of delivering content to its audience in new and exciting ways.

These strategic moves and others allowed ESPN to establish itself as the go-to sports network and one of the most recognizable brands in sports media.
